review_title: A great place for early career growth and development
pros: 1. The opportunity to work with passionate, hardworking local colleagues that genuinely care about the work they do and are often experts in their field. 2. Organizational emphasis on program quality and staff capacity building. 3. Opportunities for international travel (for expats, but not local staff). 4. Institutional knowledge management: there is a resource and a job aid for everything. 5. Positive donor reputation for consistent, high-quality programming.
cons: 1. Opaque compensation policies and well-known salary disparities between international and local staff. 2. A perception that career trajectories are often personality-driven. If a regional director or senior management likes you, they'll find a place for you. If they don't, they won't. 3. Organizational bloat at HQ and disconnect of priorities between HQ and CPs. 4. Work-life balance for middle management is extremely limited. International staff (especially PMs and HoPs) are expected to work long hours, including weekends. In the interest of being competitive for proposals, staffing is often the first to go. 5. In some contexts, overly strict, misinformed, or outdated security procedures. 6. Double standards and expectations for job performance of program and operational staff in some CPs. Annual performance evaluation processes and ratings felt mildly performative. 7. A hesitance to try new things. CRS knows what it is good at, does those things well, and doesn't try to rock the boat with donors. This makes the agency less agile and responsive than peer INGOs in some contexts.

Career opportunities seem to be most easily accessible for those who are white and fit the "development worker" profile, and are unwilling to rock the boat.

Not very progressive in how they manage people or resources.

pros: Great healthcare and other benefits. Committed and intelligent staff. Great partnerships and reputation in the international development space.
cons:
There is deep inequity and pay disparity between local and expat staff. CRS says they are pushing for equity, but recent events make me doubt that they will ever change. I have seen local staff offered laughable salaries, even when they had multiple masters degrees and years of work experience in the national government. These salaries are less than the "fellowship stipend" given to international development fellows, even though the staff would hold important positions in program management and would have much more important responsibilities than fellows. Local staff end up taking expat positions in other countries because there is no room for growth in their own country. This leads to a "brain shuffle" where people take work in neighboring countries, even though they could have a greater impact in their own.

I have heard senior staff at HQ telling international development fellows that CRS needs expats because there are not enough qualified staff in the countries where they work. This has not been my experience at all. Rather, CRS is not willing to pay qualified staff a fair salary in the countries where they work. They prefer to pay expats 2-3X a national staff salary than put forth the effort to hire and retain staff in country. 

Staff are often overworked and underpaid.

review_title: Does not respect experience and level of education
pros: Many of the technical staff are brilliant and rewarding to work with.
cons: In the past, this organization was staffed with senior technical advisors who had a wealth of experience and solid higher degrees, and whose wisdom and skills were respected. This all changed when the New Generation took over (around 2013/14). "Managers" who lack a depth of field experience and hold only a fuzzy Masters degree call the shots over those with scientific PhDs and decades of field experience. Instead of making good use of this pool of expertise, the younger less experienced managers make the decisions with respect to what more experienced and qualified staff should do, what should/should not be included in proposals and work at the field level. Highly skilled and experienced national staff are similarly not given the respect they merit, and their experience is ignored if a much younger manager deems his/her decisions to be of greater importance. Sad that this formerly strong relief and development organization has morphed into a team of less experienced and skilled managers.

review_title: An organization that takes its mission very seriously
pros: I am a current employee and enjoy very much working for CRS. The guiding principles of the agency, founded in Catholic Social Teaching, act as an important touchstone to all that we do. Having worked in other organizations where similar principles don't exist, I find this kind of anchor really very helpful. Working with colleagues who in the main believe very much in what they are doing is a big attraction for me. Whilst the work can be demanding at times, having supportive colleagues to call on, provides invaluable reassurance. There is a space at CRS to take responsibility for initiatives which encourages creativity and a strong sense of ownership around work activities; it can feel quite liberating. The agency has an overarching strategy that, from my perspective, provides me with a good sense of direction. The agency is generally staff/family friendly, or at least has been to me and my family. There is support for personal growth through annual personal development planning.
cons: I am not entirely convinced by the current staff performance appraisal system. It has the potential to be divisive since it relies on a subjective system of performance scoring that appears to award individual performance relative to others, and does not readily lend itself to my preference which is to work in a team setting. My other worry is that sometimes that agency does give the appearance of being somewhat in thrall to the private sector. My own personal bias in this regard would be that this needs to be tempered.

review_title: A place with purpose and meaning
pros: Incredibly dedicated staff who are well educated, worldly, and inspiring.  Every day can be a learning experience if you integrate yourself into learning about the programs and innovations that CRS is involved in at all levels at the organization.  Even if you are not in the field, there are many opportunities to learn through brown bags, webinars, and meeting the field staff that come into HQ.  It requires that you raise your head out of the cube and build relationships.  The opportunity to work at CRS has been transformative in blending my professional and personal desire to be more connected to our world.
cons: While it strives to promote employee engagement, and move toward a model that is keeping up with more progressive organizations, such as telecommuting and flexibility, it feels old school where some management/leaders are still caught up in face time, versus allowing people to work the way they are most productive.  Processes and Project Management are not very mature and the consensus driven nature makes decision making cumbersome and slow.  This is not across the board, and if you have a strong leader/manager, then they can help you navigate so you can get things done more efficiently.

review_title: Good for some... but know what you are getting into
pros: Note: This is written from the perspective of a program manager who worked overseas in spite of location given as Baltimore, USA. CRS is a major organization in the international development and relief industry so it has many opportunities for work overseas especially in challenging environments. For those who can work in difficult conditions, CRS offers extensive opportunity. The benefits package and conditions for international staff living overseas are good. If you are comfortable working with a Catholic organization, believe in conventional international development and relief work, and want a long-term career in developing countries, CRS is a good option.
cons: There is a tendancy to take on very large programs that are sometimes beyond the capacity of the organization to implement well. There is sometimes a conflict between CRS policies intended to promote good quality programming and pressures to execute projects that are donor driven (both public and private donors are at fault in this). Thus policies and practices in place are not followed fully in the field. Some environments are high-pressure and the workload is high, thus maintaining a good work-life balance is difficult. CRS frequently has difficulty staffing positions for highly technical work or in difficult environments thus staff who are in place have high work loads. As a large organization, CRS can be slow to innovate.

review_title: Rewarding career, great benefits, uneven management, poor back office support
pros: CRS does excellent work in challenging places. Over 3 years I worked with amazing people in several challenging countries on really important work that had an impact. Having worked at other major international NGOs in the past, I can say that CRS has comparatively more funding flexibility and deep donor relationships, which means there is a bit more flexibility to develop and implement great programs.
cons: The quality of supervisors could vary greatly. Some senior management were excellent and helped me learn a lot. Others had simply been around too long and were no longer actively engaged in their jobs. CRS has a reputation for not firing people. In addition, the back office support (finance, HR, payroll, insurance, etc) from Headquarters was generally frustrating and occasionally awful--though I hear that changing this has become a priority.

pros: Great good grand wonderful perfect
cons: nothing bad, would work there again

review_title: Research your direct supervisor before taking a field position
pros: Solid manuals, tools and structures for business development. Lots of dedicated and passionate staff particularly in the field. Strong organization from a technical standpoint in many sectors and does some great work. Solid pay and opportunity for advancement if you are able to prove yourself and get in the good graces of the right people.
cons:
As is the case with working for many INGOs in the field, one's experience greatly depends on his/her direct supervisor. My direct supervisor (country rep) repeatedly put his own career advancement and promoting his interpretation of organizational policies/HQ mandates at the forefront at the expense of staff well-being and showed very unethical ways of dealing with staff. There seemed to be lots of office politics and leadership issues across the board. 

In general, CRS has not done a great job with employing diverse staff and promoting local staff to leadership positions. Their fellows program is a way of funneling mostly young and white staff into field positions (and quickly into senior leadership roles) at the expense of developing national staff. While truly promoting localization is an issue across the aid industry, CRS does not compare favorably with many of their peers in my experience. Their senior leadership at the HQ level was overwhelmingly white at the time I was employed by them.

job_title: Program Manager I  in Baltimore, MD
pros: Catholic Relief Services has a very compelling mission based upon Catholic Social Teaching.  This approach recognizes the intrinsic human rights of all people, takes a pro-poor approach, and values working with local communities through grass roots approaches.  The organization is very good about promoting from within and there are great opportunities to move up within the organization.  With offices in just under 100 countries, international staff have lots of opportunities to travel around the world and to work on behalf of the worlds most disadvantaged populations.
cons: CRS receives much (though far from all) of their funding through the US government.  This means that CRS much match its approaches to those favored by the government.  This is particularly problematic (in my opinion) in the area of monetization, the practice through which the government provides subsidized US farm commodities to country programs around the world.  CRS then sells these commodities on the open market and uses the proceeds of the sale to finance their activities.  This approach is not supposed to negatively impact the local market, but it does.  CARE has decided not to no longer accept monetization funding, which is admirable.

review_title: Good potential, but misses the mark
pros: CRS has a good strategy that makes sense for a faith-based INGO.  There is a commitment to groom international staff to stay on a career path within the organization. CRS has a good reputation ability to influence. There are some sharp people who are dedicated to hone the focus of the NGO on some key areas. CRS has more private funds than some other INGOs, which makes it easier to do things or have cost sharing in grants. Good opportunities to meet and learn from and with other country programs.
cons: The potential for a deep connection to the Catholic Church is missed and at times CRS is very secular. Nevertheless, they are greatly swayed by right-wing Catholics. There is a distinct "mafia-like" feel with the expatriates who seem to be recycled across country programs without actually equipping them to supervise staff. "Niceness" is often used as an excuse to not speak the truth. There is a problem with confidentiality both at field and HQ levels. If you are not a CRS fellow or Catholic, you may not do well.

review_title: Used to be a great place, not so much anymore
pros: HR used to be a true leader within the organization but with changes in the HR Executive Leadership, we don't seem to be able to do that anymore.  People laugh at us.  Rather than acquire HR Talent from other HR leaders, CRS seems to be scraping bottom and bringing in leadership from much smaller organizations with much less experienced HR executives.  I don't think there is a shortage of money so I'm not quite sure what the strategy was by bringing in someone without much nonprofit experience, but whatever it is, it doesn't seem to be working.
cons: HR Executive Leadership seems to spend a lot of time blaming others within her department rather than accepting any of the blame herself.  HR Leadership seems to want to rule from an "ivory tower" rather than be "hands on"......that is when they are there.  Apparently one of our HR leaders has a little "side business" and seems "distracted" or maybe just not interested.

review_title: Great work environment, prone to bureaucracy and dogma
pros: So far in my career, colleagues at CRS were the best – elsewhere, in my experience, you'll be hard-pressed to find such great people. I was based at HQ but had many opportunities to meet field staff, all of whom are also great. I recall always receiving emotional and professional support whenever I sought it out. The work-life balance is absolutely fantastic.
cons: It's prone to bureaucracy and subservient to dogma (or perhaps as some would say, doctrine). The organization is very large, its CEO is beyond unfavorable across the board, and its executives can be a little clinically-distanced at times. As an organization it's way too hierarchical and likely won't catch up with the times where that's concerned. Pay wasn't the best. Perhaps the number one issue with CRS, however, is its artificial division between Overseas Operations and U.S. Operations, which effectively ruins many opportunities for cross-collaboration and education between domestic outreach and its actual mandate.

review_title: No longer a good place to work
pros: There is good adequate parking space for staff in the Nairobi office. Nice tall perimeter wall and very good landscaping. HQ office in Baltimore is great!
cons: The Kenya country program used to be very nice with wonderful benefits. Staff used to get severance pay an inflation adjustment every now and then. It's no longer there. Health insurance used to be very good too. Used to be very diversified organization. Change in management has brought a lot of tribalism in recruitment. Especially in operations. Hiring of relatives and non professionals is now the norm. One main "tribe" is now in charge. Led to a lot of turnover. A lot of corruption in procurement going on too. Management is aware and doesn't care to do anything about it.

review_title: CRS: Great for breaking into the international development field
pros:
CRS has a great program called the International Development Fellows program which allows recently Masters graduates or others with at least this experience to gain valuable experience in international development and project management.  Most fellows are offered a permanent position after 6-10 months.

CRS also seems to really try to follow its Catholic Social Teaching principles in the workplace.
cons:
Overseas positions generally lead you to work as a slave if you're any good at what you do, and there can be little to no work-life balance.  There is a high degree of burnout.

The managerial skills of senior staff based overseas is of varying quality and it can be difficult to maintain motivation if you end up in a country program with mediocre leadership.

job_title: M&E Specialist/Operations Research Coordinator in Tamale
pros: Catholic Relief Services is a place every employee would build his/her professional career in the highest quality expected of any individual or corporate entity. There are all the opportunities available to learn and to improve on once professional capabilities as there are platforms for continued learning on the job and through e-learning infrastructure as well.
cons: There is however room for improvement in cross country learning. Although, there are platforms such as SharePoint for information sharing and dissemination but there hardly exist TDYs which would afford employees the practical essence of what are being read on SharePoint and other media communication and information dissemination sources. Staff retention in some country programs is quite a challenge.

review_title: Good place to build an international career
pros: If you are a strong professional who works hard and are flexible, CRS can be a great place to build an international career. If you deliver quality work, CRS will work with you to accommodate life cycle needs in determining posts and transfers. You can easily be learning for your entire career as there is constantly something new to dig into and develop.
cons: If you are an international employee, you are expected to rotate posts every three to five years. This can be great if you are easily bored, but if you like to see change happen on the ground as a result of your work, this can be a negative. You need to be on your best game most of the time because the environment can be unforgiving if the wrong person gets the wrong idea about you based on one action or event.

review_title: CRS is an Amazing Place to Work!
job_title: Human Resources Benefits in Baltimore, MD
pros:
I worked for CRS for less than 3 years.  It was always an honor and a privilege to work for this organization.  I liked the fact that it wasn't perfect.  You have to climb through some unpleasant things just to get to work.  Once inside, it was truly an urban oasis, full of life and purpose.  
I will truly miss CRS and will carry all of the wonderful memories with me forever.
cons: Please embrace your differences and understand how  differences make CRS a special place to work. Besides, it would be so boring if everyone thought the same and acted the same.  My dear colleagues,  be grateful for the gift that you have been given.

review_title: Family friendly organization with good opportunities
pros:
Very family friendly
good opportunities for growth (if you have the right friends in the right places)
seeks to be transparent
values-oriented
important focus on management quality and innovation 
quality of the programs are exceptional
well-recognized and respected in the field
variety of jobs and posts available
focuses on holistic approach to development and aid work
cons:
political, especially with regard to promotions which can lead to hypocracy and disappointment 
archaic process systems that bleed inefficiency
executive leadership unable to foster culture of change and innovation among staff; behind the wheel on adopting internal process structures that promote efficiencies and management quality (a work in progress)
management and program quality sometimes work in silos, unwillingness to bridge the gaps for greater overall improvement

pros: I have worked with dozens of international development organizations (either directly, or in collaboration with their teams.)  Truthfully, I think CRS does some of the best work of all organizations.  They hire smart people and they  are truly committed to their mission.
cons: the organizations is generalist.  I went in as a specialist in the area of Small Enterprise Development... ... I left with a much more diluted focus on general management.  Yes, some SED, but lots of Health, Emergency, Education, etc.  This can be a pro or a con.... ... depends on your career objectives.  I also feel that the affilitation to the Catholic Church can be a liability.  The social justice and Catholic Social Teaching elements of their mission hold water .... ... but they still need to carry a lot of water when it comes to equal opportunity employment, birth control and cow-towing to episcopal hierarchy.

review_title: Miserable place to work, but noble mission
pros: CRS works in about 100 countries. Some of the staff people in the field are amazingly selfless and devoted to helping so many in great need. Remembering the mission keeps me going.
cons: The culture in Baltimore - and in remote US offices - is horrendously depressing and petty. I've never experienced anything like it. Lots of employee turnover, and when people leave sometimes they're traumatized by the backstabbing. No one is safe, and management as well as HR doesn't seem to care at all about abusive, exploitive, disincentivizing behavior among staff. Gossip is rampant and entire employee reviews can be written up by a supervisor based on innuendo or falsehood and the staff member is powerless. Smart, talented, good hearted people aren't appreciated, and bullies and sycophants run the place.

review_title: An organization with good values and mission ststement involved in assisting the most vulnerable in the society.
pros: CRS has good values and mission statement. It has been working in the relief and development sector for the past 60 years plus. As an organization, it acheives it goals and targets and is well respected in the countries where it operates, mainly due to committed staff and effective programming.
cons: The agency is a bit strait-jacketed and considered old fashioned. It is not seen as updated with the use of the latest technological advances to reach out to the beneficiaries and for its own operation.

pros: Seems to be some good organizational progress and company strategy and vision are being addressed. Good benefits and generally decent people. This may be a nice place to work if helping others is of interest, but that depends on what job you are looking to do.
cons: Lower pay than average in some cases. Sometimes unreasonable expectations. There is more internal chaos, both intra- and inter-departmental, than is preferable. One big downside seems to be the lack of internal support, instead much of the effort is spent on external programs and resources.

review_title: Disappointing employer where careers go to die
pros: Great mission. Staff are generally passionate about their work.  CRS works hard to ensure staff hgave a work life balance. 35 hour work week at HQ is a perk.
cons: Lots of bureaucratic tape to get anything done creates a highly prohibitive environment for enthusiasts that truly want to do great work.  Favoritism is rampant, with people in management positions that have no business being managers. Little opportunity and unclear guidelines for advancement.  Many, many staff have been there for years and have drank the cool aid, leading to complacency and the status quo.

review_title: Toxic, Nepotistic Culture With Some Good People Stuck at the Bottom
pros: Good people to work with at the HQ, field, and regional offices. The work is interesting and depending on the role you will have great experiences working around the world.
cons: A toxic institutional structure where people in power abuse, neglect, and harass staff. Some country programs are led by people that engage in or endorse racist, sexist, or otherwise abusive behavior. HR at CRS will dismiss and harass staff who report these kinds of transgressions. When you point out the mistakes of your superiors - no matter how abusive or dangerous - you will rather be the one who is punished. CRS has been known to discriminate against LGBTQ couples, and doesn't allow health insurance to cover reproductive health care.

review_title: Good work, but morale and incentives need restructuring
job_title: Technical Associate II in Baltimore, MD
pros: Morale is high and CRS finds and somehow retains some talented and committed people.
cons: HR decisions, transparency, and processes remain a mess, in spite of clear and consistent staff feedback that this is the greatest drawback and threat to the agency's long-term success and risk to it's ability to fulfill it's mission.

review_title: Generally competent field staff -- hopeless headquarters
pros: At the local level, staff are often great.  CRS does not do enough to promote national staff, but there have been improvements.
cons: CRS promotes on the basis of company loyalty or "churchiness", which guarantees that some of the very worst get power -- CRS higher management is notoriously mediocre for this reason, with very few exceptions at the top.  This is sad, when some that start with CRS are so good -- the better ones usually leave, and the duds stick around and rise (or get shifted sideways), however badly the duds perform or whatever damage has been done.

pros: CRS is a great place to work with a lot of dedicated and passionate people. CRS has a new CEO that is really well liked and respected. HR has been problematic but they recently hired a new EVP of HR that is in process of professionalizing the HR team. Lots of changes but seems like they are working hard to address long outstanding issues. Across the board, becoming less of a ‘generalist NGO’ and now hiring and developing technical expertise in core program areas, especially now that they are pursuing contracts.  Lots of new faces but also lots of people with 20 + years as the camaraderie, work environment and benefits are still pretty good.
cons: Downside is for existing employees who have lots of experience and know the agency well but have less of a technical background- career path is less clear.

review_title: More Like a Gov't Than A Nonprofit
pros:
* Best benefits I've ever had
* 35 hour work week
* Flexible Schedule
cons:
* Change comes hard - there's no designated decision makers at the middle management level, and as a result changes take forever to be approved
* Little to no collaboration between departments
* You only get promoted if you're a white Catholic

pros: None - CRS pushes deeply conservative Catholic ideas, in it's work abroad, and in it's culture for employees. It's oppressive.
cons: One of the more dysfunctional places I've ever worked. Management is a mess, and teams/roles/missions/department goals are constantly being reinvented, resulting in employees, managers, and department leaders all being on different pages. Staffers are overworked and do not get the support they need. The HR team is particularly unhelpful, and their training is a smorgasbord of disorganized bureaucracy. Turnover in my department was very high, and judging by the way I saw people treated, it's clear that staffers were seen as disposable. Management does not act with integrity, which is ironic considering how much they preach their ethics. Employee culture here is toxic. Whatever you want to do at CRS-- there are better places out there to do it.

pros: Field staff outside USA are selfless and dedicated
cons: Not the most Christian organization, despite their name. They really don't care about you. Small minds and mean spirits at US HQ in Baltimore. Mediocrity is the gold standard -- they are not open to new ideas or collaboration. Lots of backbiting, mean talk and cliques - worse than in high school! Don't rock the boat or you will be ostracized and criticized. Frequent use of bogus "Performance Improvement Plans" to force employees to quit. Highly dysfunctional. Almost everyone hates it there but they need the work. No opportunities for advancement. Relatively low salaries.

review_title: worthy organization but could benefit from improved organizational efficiency
pros: mission driven, committed to serving the base of the pyramid, "need not creed"; relatively good expat benefits; local staff is valued and capacity building of local staff is significant; integrity and ethics of the organization and all staff that I had contact with were beyond reproach
cons: not very plugged in to technology advancement or systematized, paperless workflows; not always up to date with cutting edge sector-specific, technical advances; not very good transition planning or internal communications; employees treated like expendable contractors

review_title: Excellent workplace if you cultivate the right relationships
pros: Wide global and sectoral coverage allows almost limitless scope for personal and professional development. Friendly, interesting and supportive colleagues. Some policies and systems are clear and well-run. Educational support and some flex-time.
cons: Staff care and safety are extremely low priority. Program and management quality vary dramatically between regions of the world. Focus is increasingly on mobilizing funding, at the expense of quality programs. Little to no comp time for extremely long working hours. A difficult place for women to work.

review_title: A great organization to work for
pros:
Humble and mission-driven
Strong technical expertise on the ground
Excellent local reputation among beneficiaries
High program quality and research rigor
Supportive environment of promoting a healthy work-life balance
cons: Difficult to get at the root cause of a lot of public health issues without addressing some topics that go against Catholic social teaching (ex. contraception, problematic STD/HIV prevention approach, problematic sex ed approach)

review_title: Good Mission, Lot of Work, New Experiences
pros: CRS is a great place to gain responsibility and get experience on your resume.  They have great project management tools. Most employees are very dedicated to the mission and vision.  You will work with all types of stakeholders.  Religion does not have to do with the majority of the project that you will manage overseas. They serve everyone regardless of faith.
cons: It can be hard place to use or develop technical skills if you are a technical expert.  Depending on the position there can be quite a bit of travel.  You are often expected to work overtime in the office and on calls at night. Different offices are different. Some positions ask for too many qualifications.

pros:
Compelling mission and vision
Relatively innovative approach to programming, compared to other similar organizations
Large reserves of private funding allow for flexibility in programming approaches
Strong partnership focus
cons:
Inconsistent care of employees, specifically on promoting healthy work-life balance and providing adequate resources to meet job expectations
Needs a significant Human Resources update to better assess capacity based on an employees total work experience, not just experience with CRS, and also to provide a more equitable forum for employees to provide feedback to the upper management.

review_title: A wonderful opportunity for recent graduates.
pros:
As a fellow, you have a fantastic opportunity to learn all about the organization and it is very likely that you will be kept on as a program manager if you do a good job.

A great chance to learn programming and administration nuances and develop professionally.
cons:
You often have little control over what you work on or where you're asked to go next (which is often a hardship post - be prepared).

Sometimes the role of the fellow is unclear.

pros: Great and friendly working environment! No stress. You just need to have your work well done. Zero discrimination. The very best and effect whistle blow system I've ever seen for my past 7 years of professional career. You feel confident.
cons: Low wages for local staff. Also, the policy to promote local staff sometimes let's below the average staff to take over important positions which are beyond their ability. It takes time to train and become effective in their new role which sometimes have a negative impact. Pact on the operations. Still some room for improvement on that point.

review_title: Great mission and great people to work with!
pros: I have been here 11 years and fully believe that CRS is a great place to work.  Great mission, great people, and good compensation for the nonprofit sector.   People deeply care about the mission and work hard.  We attract some of the best and the brightest in the nonprofit sector so it can be hard to get a job here.  But if you come you will probably stay for a long time.  Our turnover rate is low.   CRS is also self-critical is a good way - always pushing to improve because we want to do better as we strive to serve 100+ million people around the developing world who want to create a better life for themselves and their families.  I came here 11 years ago because I was looking for a rewarding but challenging career.  Like many others at CRS, I strive to become a "servant leader" - someone who tries to  leads by serving others, especially those who are living at the margins of our global society. It is really challenging work and equally rewarding.
cons:
We are big and complex with 5000 staff members worldwide but also strive to become a family.  This spirit may be uneven across every unit working across 91+ countries but it is fairly widespread.   Also, I have found work/life balance is hard not because of CRS' policies, which are family friendly,  but because the urgency of this mission compels me to work more than I should.   

Bottom line:  A 3.5 rating on this site is not good enough.   We can make it better but only by listening to our staff who really are the heart of this organization.   How can we make it better?  How can we get our rating up to 4.5 to 4.9?  (No organization is perfect so "5" is probably not an option. Only God gets a 5.)

pros: the inspiring, compelling mission, the great work CRS does with partners, the talented, dedicated staff, the continuous improvement focus
cons: little to no guiding of staff trying to stay w/CRS yet move to different parts of the organization or transition from overseas to HQ or vice versa; little support for staff and families adjusting to a new life overseas or returning to the US after multiple years/tours overseas.  No policies or systematic ways of addressing work-life balance.  Heavy workloads and long hours for middle and senior manager positions.

pros: Family friendly organization. Considers family,  married couples and nursing mothers during making staff benefits decisions. For example,  there is children education support up to four children; maternity leave of up to ninety days with flexible working hours for the next six months of resumption from maternity leave; paternity leave of six days for the male folks. Mini crèche for nursing mothers.
cons: There are Promotion delays in some projects. Unequal treatment of Staff of different projects. Relevance is given more to staff of projects with higher grant monetary value. This creates an atmosphere of rancor and insidious acrimony. Eroding self-confidence of affected staff with little or no assistance from the management.

pros: good learning opportunities, good education policy for employee, gender equality, employees oriented policies. conducive and friendly environment environment. All members are like family members.
cons: At local level, mean at country level, sub-offices are headed by the local staff who prefer to appoint their kith and kins, and least preference is given to talented and experienced staff. international staff should be hired as head of office at each country level, particularly in Pakistan.

review_title: Great Place to Work w/ Minor Drawbacks
pros: It's a great organization with a reputation for transparency and honesty, even in some of the most otherwise corrupt countries. It's accommodating to families. Very much seeks to empower local staff and beneficiaries. Those at entry and mid levels have a great deal more autonomy than at other organizations.
cons: It can at times feel like that employees are expected to live like missionaries or closer to the local counterparts. Compared to other NGOs, there is lower pay, less benefits (i.e. small per diem amounts) and an insistence in lodging in poor quality hotels, all in the interest of saving a few dollars here and there.

review_title: Great if you know the right people
pros:
Reasonable benefits
Most staff have good intentions
cons:
Nepotism rather than capability will get you far
When you are on top you can never be fired even if you know next to nothing about how to manage your staff
Staff care is very poor and inconsistent from country to country
Antiquated systems make serving those in need painful and unnecessarily convoluted

pros: Many great people work here and the mission of helping poor is commendable. Benefits are fairly good and the physical work environment is also good. A nice renovation of an old building was done.
cons: The overall culture of the organization is dismal. People are overworked, often asked to do two jobs for the pay of one. Very little respect is given to employees who do a good job or to older workers who have a depth of experience. It has become a place where the more you do, the more gets piled on you. Promotion depends not on what you know and do but who you know. People are brought in for interviews but management already knows who they are going to give the open position to, usually one of their buddies!!! Older employees are "encouraged" to retire as there is definitely a youth culture. Political correctness is overblown to the point of being restrictive! Management is not supportive of people they direct. The HR staff is inflated to the point of no one takes responsibility to actually support existing staff and questions are handed off to others - often 4 or 5 times - before an employee can get an answer...and often that answer is "go to the self help section on the intranet and you will find your answers."  I worked at CRS for more than 15 years and saw the culture deteriorate from a warm friendly place to work to a cut-throat corporate culture where very little value was placed on employees with depth of experience. Sad as it used to be a good place to work. The way it is now, I would never recommend it to anyone as a good place to work. Too much stress, too little recognition for a job well done.

review_title: It has been a wonderful journey with CRS which is still going strong
pros: An agency that has a big heart and cares about its team members, partners along with the community.  The agency cares about the family of the employee and provides all kinds of support to ease functioning at the ground level.  Senior people are extremely humble and supportive.
cons: Too process oriented which often leads to wastage of time and energy.  Many a times it feels as compulsive or nagging issue than a real need for undergoing the process.

pros:
The mission of the organization is a great purpose. 
The opportunity to lend a helping hand is great way to give back to the communities around the world. By doing so I've experienced appreciation on new level.
cons: Direct management support is limited. The glass ceiling is triple stacked against your progress. It is rather difficult to cross-train and gain new prospective as the opportunity isn't ideal. You'll always have work to complete, especially when coworkers do not complete their work.

pros:
Collegiality: CRS brings colleagues together multiple times a year in order to 
1) share best practices
2) evaluate progress
3) share new information that affects our work
4) learn new skills that will impact our relationship building
5) relax in an atmosphere of enjoyment

Travel Overseas and visiting programs that reflect the work
cons: pay is not even for employees with the same job description and length of service; supervisors have minimal skills in directing their staff; the process for managerial staff improvement is hidden; goal setting and development is difficult to understand, apply, and learn from;

job_title: Senior Relationship Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Mission!  Colleagues are dedicated, hard working, open to learning together; International travel/learning; the environment is justice orientated and respectful of other faiths.
cons: Because of its "Catholic Church" ties Catholic Relief Services is under tremendous attack by many "limited thinking" Catholics; the leadership of CRS handles the criticism well but the attacks are a drain on energy;

review_title: Great org programmatically with poor HR department
pros: large organization; lots of opportunities for movement
cons: LGBT discrimination is a problem - e.g. CRS doesn’t provide health benefits to same-sex spouses but they do for opposite-sex spouses. This is just one example of LGBT discrimination.

pros:
Excellent programming and learning opportunities. Great opportunity for growth.  
Good pay with great benefits, generous housing allowance, generous COLA, great employees. The management team and the organization in general seems to focus on the needs of those of us who work overseas.
cons: The management team in the field could be better leaders and managers;

review_title: Good external work. Internal things need a lot of work.
pros:
They really have a great mission, stemming from Catholic social teachings. They do not discriminate on the basis of your religion (although it appears that being a Catholic is a prerequisite if you are to go high up the organization like Director level and beyond), but you would have to resonate well with the values central to Catholic Faith. 

Most of their work on the ground really are amazing. They have extensive internal resources which makes your work easier within the organization. They way they design and organize their programs are great and they try to standardize the process as much as possible. 

The benefits of international staff are great and salary is good too. There is a fairly healthy representation of women among international staff.
cons:
There appears to be different treatment with national staff and international staff for the same position. For instance, when recruiting for a Program Manager (National), they would require more than 5 years of specialized experience (e.g. agriculture, health, etc.). But when recruiting for a Program Manager (International), 2 years of general experience is enough. And as mentioned in other reviews, most of their international staff are white Americans. And somehow, when white Americans are the hiring managers, they tend to hire another white American. I wonder why.

If you are a non-white American, chances of you going up the chain is rather slim, unless you would like to be assigned in a conflict country. There are only a couple of countries where they hired locals/non-white Americans as the country representative.

As with most iNGOs, they tend to publish JDs and conduct interviews even though they already have someone in mind for the post just to comply with rules. This just wastes everyone's time and effort. Also, sometimes, their scoring system in the interview does not matter. The top interviewee won't get the job if someone higher up (e.g. from the region) wants another candidate to fill the post. And they will fill you with excuses. 

They promote good work-life balance ... but when you actually request for some days off, the tone of your hiring manager tends to be different.

pros:
- Mission and values are exceptional and not just lip service
- Financial stewardship (work done for the money spent) is a top priority
- They do their best to keep good employees around and WILL focus on your professional development. They treat their people well.
- Good sense of camaraderie amount employees
*I was an based international and cannot speak for HQ
cons: - Very hierarchical (which is a pro and con in my opinion) and your experience with the organization can be very dependent on the country program or region where you work.

review_title: A great place to grow professionally
pros: A great organization with a very dedicated senior management. Plenty of opportunities to grow professionally and a great community to have personally. CRS is all about staff care, so it's great for family people that want some flexibility now and then.
cons:
Varying levels of program quality depending on the country program which is not entirely CRS' fault. Also, some national staff stay for years even with less than adequate performance which demotivates those who work hard 
As all other NGOs, networking and knowing people within the organizations goes a long way

pros: Does great work in some areas. Traditionally was a great employer with excellent benefits. Staff are generally bright, idealistic, and committed to the mission. Is well regarded for emergency response.
cons: Is becoming a more traditional employer: reducing benefits, cutting staff. Depends on outside consultants for policy and product development with uneven results. Is constrained by theology.

pros: Great Benefits. Potential internal advancement but totally based on your supervisor's discretion. Competitive salaries for an NGO. Familly oriented and opportunities for training.
cons: Tend to hire third country nationals for expat positions especially in the field of Finance and Operations.

pros: This has been a good opportunity to gain field experience in Africa and breakaway from the HQ culture. I am pleased with the diversity of staff and long-track record of the organization as a whole.
cons: High turnover creates chaos, creates uncertain expectations and contributes to low morale. I would like to see more accountability from the top for middle managers in particular.

pros: You're working for a great cause and doing some good in the world which is one of the reasons why I love it so much despite the cons. You see real results and help real people. I don't receive benefits because I'm part-time, but I know for a fact they have GREAT benefits. Everyone is super friendly. Free food a lot!!!!
cons: HR has NO IDEA what they're doing. Most of them are clueless for the most part.

review_title: Practice what you preach (in terms of values)
pros: good place to get experience in the industry. Depending on who your supervisors/mentors are, you can climb up in the agency and get a wide array of exposure. this is not always the case in other humanitarian aid and development agencies.
cons: rarely learns from past mistakes. in denial about its own shortcomings.

pros: Great opportunity to travel abroad, work with nationals, and get to know the program management of Catholic Relief Services in terms of proposal development, project set up, implementation, and M&E.and In addition, there was time spend with beneficiaries in the field, which was very positive and rewarding.
cons: Management capability and professionalism is inconsistent throughout the organization, as I was able to compare to my base office, another office of temporary assignment and interactions with HQ.

review_title: Overall, a good place to work
pros: flexible hours, coworkers are passionate and feel called to the mission, CRS has a great reputation as a highly effective aid organization is many places, my supervisor cares about my well being and my interests
cons: not all colleagues have a good work-life balance, things can be slow moving because CRS is such a big organization, large work load, few opportunities to move up depending on your area of work, CRS is a big organization so many people could very different experiences

pros: Great place to work, flexible working hours, attractive salary and benefit, great opportunity for staff development, big grant portfolio for most Country programs, good funding opportunities and highly self sustainable, strong leadership team
cons: Great strategies but less action; lack of merit in staff recruitment at international levels; salaries and remuneration not based on the grades, skills and competencies

pros: Great staff, benefits and doing wonderful work.
cons: Lack of clear decision making and vision under new leadership, no loyalty to staff, little to no care for employees. Staff who gave decades of their life are thrown away if they respectfully question leadership. Burnout and multiple roles with no salary increase is the norm. New leadership is lacking clarity of vision and strategy for achieving it.

review_title: Its a good organization that can help you in learning new skills and development components
pros:
- Continuous employees training.
- Availability to be promoted and apply for internal positions.
- Learning about project management , preparing proposals, relations with partners.
cons:
- Low Salary packages in comparison between some NGOs.
- Prefer to hire internal employees than give an opportunity to other external candidates despite of they made short list and a lot of interviews and test to external employees

pros: Lots of proactive learning and advancement opportunities.
cons: Salary scales btn the SAME positions are very differing without transparency of why. Salary discussions come across as being a very sensitive topic and its always made to seem like they are doing you a favor. Negotiation of salary are also not very welcomed. This has been the case for me personally working across different regions and departments. Work-life balance is extremely poor.

review_title: CRS is a very good organization with clear focus and good values.
pros: Good family and work balance, good organizational culture, Salary and benefits within the current market rates
cons: Unclear career growth path, Recycling of very old employees who are beyond retirement age. The organization could also improve on the technological aspect.

review_title: The Best in the Biz, but Executive Leadership Slow to Change
pros:
* Amazing quality of development work. The best.
* Once you're in, you're family, and will be taken care of.
* Good working hours.
cons:
* Does not provide benefits to those in same-sex marriages.
* Senior leadership slow to change, not always willing to take on new change.
* The per diems that you receive here will be half those you'd receive at other organizations or with the USG, so plan your salary level accordingly.

pros: CRS is very good at serving the poor and vulnerable. They promote integral human development and I believe they take it seriously, when it comes to their beneficiaries.
cons: They strongly favor management over the individual contributor. They have zero interest in listening to the individual contributor’s needs or perspective, even when the employee is asking to be heard, they are ignored.

pros: Great work environment and dedicated staff at headquarters and in the field. Decent compensation among its peers. Depending on your department, you have the opportunity for real impact with your work.
cons: Being located in Baltimore is a major con.While compensation is fair, not as competitive as some NGOs in DC and elsewhere. Being big, it is not super nimble, but does make efforts at staying innovative and relevant.

pros: I truly enjoyed my time at CRS. I got to network and work with so many great and highly qualified individuals. There was a great work life balance while I was there and the everybody was always friendly. You can tell people actually loved what they did
cons: I can't really think of anything. I loved my internship and who knows maybe I will work there someday!

review_title: Have extensive experience in working in food aid warehouses around Zimbabwe since 2005 to date.
pros: Its a company with excellent working conditions and there is a lot of on the job trainings offered.Its renumeration is good and it offers greater career advancement if you are interested.
cons: The work depends on funding.They dont employ full time.They have contractswhich are mostly less than a year.

review_title: HR employees operate like social workers.
pros: Great benefits.  Okay pay.
cons:
Poor Leadership.  Not enough minorities in management positions.  HR operates like social services rather than a business partner.

Managers are not given the training and tools they need in order to be successful in their roles.

pros:
-They really value employees and provide flexibility to people based on their life situations if they are interested in keeping that employee around. 
-Dedicated staff at all levels of the organization
cons:
-HQ is very church-driven as you might expect, which sometimes can be frustrating when you're working in the field in a context very far from church politics and dogma
-Work/life balance is often hard to find
-Compensation is below industry standards

review_title: Gained valuable experience, went through a transitional time
pros: Was given opportunity to develop project management skills in an area that I had worked in for some time. Decent pay.
cons: It was a time of transition, which could have been handled in a better manner

review_title: Gained valuable experience, went through a transitional time
pros: Was given opportunity to develop project management skills in an area that I had worked in for some time. Decent pay.
cons: It was a time of transition, which could have been handled in a better manner

pros: The work done by CRS benefits those who are less fortunate than we are.  It was important to me that I was helping out another person as I worked
cons: CRS is too big a company.  There is a lot of discrimination; Managers have the ability to fire you because of personal differences, espcially in the field offices

job_title: Multimedia Content Producer in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Benefits and work schedule good for those with children and families
Amicable Office culture
I enjoyed my coworkers
Office had random free food around on different floor you could forage through
Managers are understanding, not micromanaging.
Facilitated many out of office activities
cons:
Different departments were our clients but they didn't have much knowledge of video work so some asks were unreasonable and unnecessary.
Pay schedule was a little annoying

review_title: I consider a black period of my life in CRS(Lucknow)
pros:
Core ngo team is good and have healthy environment,
company is good to work but not osdu(lucknow team)
cons: In OSDU (IT team) senior management(technical advisories,delivery heads ) are blood suckers, they dont know how to manage single project from last two year and shamelessly sitting on the higher post only pressurizing the team making the life hell for developers.

review_title: minorities are treated incredibly second rate
job_title: Middle Level Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros: Usefully connected to field
cons: Definitely a company with a southern mentality as minorities are treated as second rate inferior to white staff.  Across the board, black representation and voice is almost non-exist. One of the least transformed organizations I've worked for in my career.

job_title: Responsible of Administrative and Finance in Bujumbura
pros: my reason to work on this position is that i have experience in and it related to my studies
cons: sometime you can find yoursel facing  on different challenges or conflict,you have to be able to solve it .

pros: Friendly atmosphere, people very approachable. Great learning opportunities within the agency. Accommodating for family situations.
cons: Reluctance to let go of staff who underperform, rather shift them to another country. Very little work life balance, as staff are expected to work long hours and over weekends regularly

review_title: Program Manager II / Head of Operations
pros: It is an organization with a mission to serve the poor.
cons: It is important to ensure a proper and comprehensive onboarding process is followed for new staff to CRS to ensure they are provided with optimal development and growth opportunities.

review_title: Great mission, but employees are not treated equitably. Wide disparity in work life balance.
pros:
The global programs that help the poor and oppressed are exciting and groundbreaking.
The benefits are good although they are cutting back.
cons: Unfortunately the emphasis on good stewardship of resources does not take into account the employees time and energy.

pros: Benefits, health insurance, career oportunities, organizonal enviroment is very good, family friendly, national employee salaries are above average, education assistance program
cons: Dificults to embrace change withing the organization,   old time employees  have been doing a great job por many years, so they face problems to overcome change because they dont see a need on that

pros: The organisation has the best systems that can aid your work and you have the opportunity to gain more technical skill through a lot of online training available.
cons: The work-life balance is difficult to attain because each position at the organisation has a JD that is highly expectant from the employee.

review_title: Good people that work hard for a cause caught in government bureaucracy
pros: It is great to work with people who are so cause-driven
cons: It's challenging to work for an organization which is majority funded by the US Government. Through that funding the organization loses some of its identity and is hindered from being as efficient as it could and achieving its core mission.

pros: Dynamic place.  Great mission. Fantastic people. Good funding support. World-wide reach.  Works with partners.  Solid strategic plan.
cons: Workload is high at times.  Often too many priorities.  Internal communication could be better.

review_title: Great work environment with few growth opportunities unless you work so hard to prove that you deserve such opportunity
job_title: Program Officer in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: It depends on the country program you work in, but in general you will get attached to the agency so easily as a lot of good things happens in terms of serving people in need.
cons: There is a lot to be done.

pros: Recognized International NGO.  Great working environment. Opportunity to learn and grow.  Fringe benefits above local law.  Integral development work.
cons: Stressful.  Long hours required.  Heavy work-load.  Family-work balance sometimes difficult to achieve.

pros:
Good training and development benefits. A room to grow and gain experience
Helping the world of need and meet their the satisfaction
cons: There are many cons: (i)salaries are out of comparison with the market. (ii) there is no management nor monitoring in sub-offices the head office is totally away of the sub-offices. (iii) unhealthy working environment with not equality.

review_title: Clueless executive leadership; avoid at all costs
pros: In theory, it will make you feel good to know that you are helping the less fortunate
cons: In reality, you will be mistreated and stepped on by those above you or those looking to climb up the ladder without ethics or integrity

pros: CRS offers development opportunities to staff, and generally good job security. The work is interesting and staff are passionate about the mission.
cons: So much depends on who your supervisor and their supervisor are, and how well they like and support you.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Good staff.  
Good belief in the mission to help others.
If based overseas, there are good opportunities to move up the career path and get experience in different sectors and different countries.
Good benefits.
cons:
The career path at HQ is not so clear/linear. 
Salaries are not that high - though benefits are good.

job_title: Project Manager II in Baltimore, MD
pros: Schedule flexibility; generous HR policies, way better than the industry standard; kind and caring staff
cons: Lack of growth within the HQ; limited salary increases. Variety of parallel opportunities available, however, most experienced employees work for several years, even decades, until they reach senior management level position/compensation.

pros: I was an intern for two summers at headquarters. It was a great learning experience, I learned more about what I needed to know and had the opportunity to attend seminars and a conference. Very supportive and friendly coworkers. Great professional development and work experience for college students
cons: I can't think of any

job_title: Customer Care Benefits Specialist in Chesapeake, VA
pros: The office culture was enjoyable on a lower employee level; however on a management level it was tense
cons: Promotions from within were minimal and the compensation was not up to industry standards.

review_title: The Internal Audit function is blamed for internal control failures.
pros: The organization is headquartered in the heart of the inner city.
cons: The Internal Audit Director reports to the CFO, which is a conflict of interest.  Consequently, financial internal control failures are blamed on the internal audit function.  There is no accountability for agency finances since the internal audit function is strictly controlled by the CFO, which could result in significant legal liabilities for the Internal Audit Director.

review_title: Great org but too much red tape
pros: friendly people, several rpcvs to connect with, hard working people
cons: poor management skills in certain country programs, people have to get through the fellows program which is a waste
